Hello, my name is Tavinder
And I'm lucky if I use English right.

To help me help you...
this is what this is all about.
Follow?

Over the years I've been fortuante enough to have people become "Tav Fluent" in understnading (<-- like that) my attempts at spelling, using the english language in spoken words and badely written early morning emails. All of this leads to some level of confusion in my miss use of words, idioms (or combining idioms), and creating new words in what are called 'tavisms.' Sometimes my statistics talk is confused for 'tavisms' - I'm okay with that.

If you have not yet been subjected to such Tom Foolery... well then, you may not be actually talking to me and I you!

To be honest, I don't remember many of the 'isms' as I write this, and there have been various lists of my 'isms' made including my person favourite: a 'large sticky post it' on my office door where people kept running out of meetings to add to. I took a picture of it, but cannot seem to find it. Like all good things, it should stay in memory, but never to be recovered.

FYI

Sometimes, I just pretend these are all British slangs to confuse my readers, and listeners...

Idiom Confusion/Combined

I get a lot of idioms wrong, combined or just mis-aligned to meet my own needs from its purpose or creation. Most common ones include:


The horse has left the cart somewhere = 'The cart has left the horse.' Wait, I cannot even tell if this is right anymore. What is the saying?


The bag has left the cat = 'The cat is out of the bag.' <-- but what I'm really saying is cover your eyes, its going to get ugly... when I use this one.


Coal in the Cannery mind = I later discovered this was "Cannary in the coal mine." And then still don't use it right


Read herring = I thought this was all 'signal' look at me! Apparently its a distractor! All these years, I often wondered why people didn't take my point serious when I used this saying. I now know why.


Play it by year = "Play it by ear"

Made up Words

I smush a lot of words together. The most common one:


Whoppins if = what happines ... if

Miss-Pronunciations

I struggle with the following:


Pleuthra = plenthra, ple-thra, lots and lots of...

Rural (argh!) = ruler, rurrraaallallarrr

Anecdotal = anikdote, anci-dotal... this one is a personal nightmare.


Sometimes it is a 'you say tomato, I say tomoto--- moment...' probably 25% of the time, but I'll take those odds.


E.g.,

Lieu vs. Lief-tant

Musle-skel-etal vs. Musco-skull-e-tal

Tav Fluency

Apparently its a thing! And it has a correlated with happiness!

Take all of this with a grain of salt that is diluted in coffee inside a partially solved rubric's cube spinning on a wobbling axis of a top...
That is the leg I stand on. That is the moose in the street.

PS. I do a lot of silly things, like making this webstie the day before my 41st birthday.



ENJOY!



If this is all too much Take me to the kittens (Aka SPSS tutorials).
